articles.headline: South Korea and U.S. Reach Deal on Trade
articles.snippet: A free-trade agreement that is the largest since 1994 was reached weeks after President Obama’s deadline after both sides agreed to more time to eliminate tariffs on autos.
articles.abstract: A free-trade agreement that is the largest since 1994 was reached weeks after President Obama’s deadline after both sides agreed to more time to eliminate tariffs on autos.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  American negotiators have completed a free-trade agreement with South Korea that will eliminate most tariffs on exports and solidify one of the nation’s most significant alliances in Asia, the Obama administration said on Friday.

articles.headline: Why Savings Account Rates Are So Pathetic
articles.snippet: Financial institutions are paying next to nothing on savings accounts and not much more on certificates of deposit. What’s a saver to do?
articles.abstract: Financial institutions are paying next to nothing on savings accounts and not much more on certificates of deposit. What’s a saver to do?
articles.lead_paragraph: Savers just can’t catch a break.

articles.headline: In Smartphone Era, Point-and-Shoots Stay Home
articles.snippet: The point-and-shoot camera is being shoved aside for the smartphone camera that improves with each new model.
articles.abstract: The point-and-shoot camera is being shoved aside for the smartphone camera that improves with each new model.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ariel Dunitz-Johnson, a 30-year-old illustrator in San Francisco, bought a point-and-shoot camera in May. But in July, she bought a smartphone, with a camera built in.

articles.headline: Yemen Sets Terms of a War on Al Qaeda
articles.snippet: Cables offer an intimate view of the Yemeni leader, who has become steadily more aggressive against Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: Cables offer an intimate view of the Yemeni leader, who has become steadily more aggressive against Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  One Obama administration security official after another was visiting to talk about terrorism, and Yemen’s redoubtable president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, seemed to be savoring his newfound leverage.

articles.headline: A Happy Ending to a Raw, but Common, Tale
articles.snippet: Lilla Roberts fell behind on her mortgage for a while over a paying history of around 20 years. But her modification was so sloppily handled, she could have lost her home.
articles.abstract: Lilla Roberts fell behind on her mortgage for a while over a paying history of around 20 years. But her modification was so sloppily handled, she could have lost her home.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lilla Roberts is a 73-year-old retired physical therapist, a pleasant, engaging woman who moved to this country from Jamaica 46 years ago. In 1988, she bought a small house in Jamaica, Queens, putting down $25,000, and taking out a mortgage for around $120,000. For many years, she religiously made her mortgage payments.

articles.headline: Panel Votes to Expand Surgery for Less Obese
articles.snippet: Current guidelines say weight-loss surgery is appropriate for people who have failed to lose weight through diet and exercise and have a body mass index of 40 and above.
articles.abstract: Current guidelines say weight-loss surgery is appropriate for people who have failed to lose weight through diet and exercise and have a body mass index of 40 and above.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal advisory panel Friday endorsed an expansion of the use of Allergan’s Lap-Band stomach-restricting device to patients who are less than severely obese.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Weigh Deal to Extend Tax Cuts for All
articles.snippet: Negotiators are discussing a deal to extend all of the Bush-era tax cuts, perhaps for two years, after an Obama plan to let rates rise for top incomes failed in the Senate.
articles.abstract: Negotiators are discussing a deal to extend all of the Bush-era tax cuts, perhaps for two years, after an Obama plan to let rates rise for top incomes failed in the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Saturday rejected President Obama’s proposal to let tax rates rise for the highest-income Americans, as Republicans held firm in their push to continue all of the expiring Bush-era tax cuts.

articles.headline: Vast Hacking by a China Fearful of the Web
articles.snippet: China has engaged in attacks aimed at American military and political data, and its leaders have been obsessed with Google’s role in its country, cables say.
articles.abstract: China has engaged in attacks aimed at American military and political data, and its leaders have been obsessed with Google’s role in its country, cables say.
articles.lead_paragraph: As China ratcheted up the pressure on Google to censor its Internet searches last year, the American Embassy sent a secret cable to Washington detailing one reason top Chinese leaders had become so obsessed with the Internet search company: they were Googling themselves.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and John Markoff

articles.headline: So That’s Where the Money Went
articles.snippet: Knowing who got what at the bailout banquet helps us understand how expensive it is to live in a nation where big financial institutions are not allowed to fail.
articles.abstract: Knowing who got what at the bailout banquet helps us understand how expensive it is to live in a nation where big financial institutions are not allowed to fail.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW the truth shines through when you shed a little light on a subject.

articles.headline: G.E. Goes With What It Knows: Making Stuff
articles.snippet: Jeffrey Immelt, G.E.’s chief executive, says the company must rely more on making physical products and less on financial engineering.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey Immelt, G.E.’s chief executive, says the company must rely more on making physical products and less on financial engineering.
articles.lead_paragraph: TO train its future leaders, General Electric has rising young stars study and visit an array of different organizations, from Google to West Point.

articles.headline: After a Rough Night, Hotel Investors Are Waking Up
articles.snippet: Private equity funds and entrepreneurs like Richard Branson are hunting for deals in the hotel sector, and many are under the gun to buy earlier rather than later.
articles.abstract: Private equity funds and entrepreneurs like Richard Branson are hunting for deals in the hotel sector, and many are under the gun to buy earlier rather than later.
articles.lead_paragraph: IS this as bad as it gets? For two years, big investors watched the implosion of the lodging industry as hotel values plummeted more than 50 percent. Now as private equity giants like the Blackstone Group and entrepreneurs like Richard Branson are diving into the sector, others are starting to think it has finally hit bottom and may be bouncing back.

articles.headline: Taking Sides in a Divorce, Chasing Profit
articles.snippet: A small number of companies are seeing profit in the often contentious and emotional process of ending a marriage.
articles.abstract: A small number of companies are seeing profit in the often contentious and emotional process of ending a marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Michelle Pont and her husband amassed millions of dollars in properties and investments from a freight-hauling business that they started with a single stake-bed truck in 1991. They bought a four-bedroom home, then a second home, a vacation home, a motor home and half a dozen cars.

articles.headline: As Bullies Go Digital, Parents Play Catch-Up
articles.snippet: Parents trying to protect their children from Internet bullying are scrambling to catch up with the technology.
articles.abstract: Parents trying to protect their children from Internet bullying are scrambling to catch up with the technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ninth grade was supposed to be a fresh start for Marie’s son: new school, new children. Yet by last October, he had become withdrawn. Marie prodded. And prodded again. Finally, he told her.

articles.headline: Mounting Debts by States Stoke Fears of Crisis
articles.snippet: State budget imbalances remind some analysts of the run-up to the subprime mortgage meltdown, or of the crisis hitting Europe.
articles.abstract: State budget imbalances remind some analysts of the run-up to the subprime mortgage meltdown, or of the crisis hitting Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: The State of Illinois is still paying off billions in bills that it got from schools and social service providers last year. Arizona recently stopped paying for certain organ transplants for people in its Medicaid program. States are releasing prisoners early, more to cut expenses than to reward good behavior. And in Newark, the city laid off 13 percent of its police officers last week.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Pushing a Right to Bear Arms, the Sharp Kind
articles.snippet: Changes in knife laws in Arizona and New Hampshire have given new life to the knife rights lobby.
articles.abstract: Changes in knife laws in Arizona and New Hampshire have given new life to the knife rights lobby.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Arizona used to be a knife carrier’s nightmare, with a patchwork of local laws that forced those inclined to strap Buck knives or other sharp objects to their belts to tread carefully as they moved from Phoenix (no knives except pocketknives) to Tempe (no knives at all) to Tucson (no knives on library grounds).

articles.headline: Cash Flow to Terrorists Evades U.S. Efforts
articles.snippet: American officials say that millions of dollars are going to extremist groups and that some Middle East allies are not helping to stop it.
articles.abstract: American officials say that millions of dollars are going to extremist groups and that some Middle East allies are not helping to stop it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Nine years after the United States vowed to shut down the money pipeline that finances terrorism, senior Obama administration officials say they believe that many millions of dollars are flowing largely unimpeded to extremist groups worldwide, and they have grown frustrated by frequent resistance from allies in the Middle East, according to secret diplomatic dispatches.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Pressure Rises to Bolster European Bailout Fund
articles.snippet: A Belgian minister and the International Monetary Fund want a stronger scope of measures to stabilize the euro.
articles.abstract: A Belgian minister and the International Monetary Fund want a stronger scope of measures to stabilize the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: European finance ministers are under mounting pressure to significantly increase the 750 billion-euro rescue fund for the currency union when they meet Monday.

articles.headline: Madoff Suit Cites HSBC as a Helper
articles.snippet: A suit seeks $9 billion from several defendants headed by HSBC, the London-based financial giant.
articles.abstract: A suit seeks $9 billion from several defendants headed by HSBC, the London-based financial giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: The trustee seeking assets for victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s global Ponzi scheme filed a lawsuit on Sunday seeking $9 billion from a roster of defendants headed by HSBC, the London-based financial giant with hedge fund clients that fed piles of cash into the enormous fraud.

articles.headline: Tax Fear May Move Bonuses Earlier
articles.snippet: Worried that lawmakers will let taxes rise for the richest, firms have studied whether to move their payouts from next year to this month.
articles.abstract: Worried that lawmakers will let taxes rise for the richest, firms have studied whether to move their payouts from next year to this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Congress is debating tax rates, and that has Wall Street nervously eyeing the calendar.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: To Beat ‘Today,’ Look to Tomorrow
articles.snippet: At the CBS “Early Show,” the entire team got fired. Better to stop playing a well-nigh unwinnable game.
articles.abstract: At the CBS “Early Show,” the entire team got fired. Better to stop playing a well-nigh unwinnable game.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a sports team loses long enough, fans get restless and soon enough, the coach ends up getting the gate. After all, you can’t fire the whole team, right?

articles.headline: Bush Tax-Cut Deal With Jobless Aid Said to Be Near
articles.snippet: Congressional Republicans and administration officials said they were close to a deal to keep the Bush-era tax cuts temporarily.
articles.abstract: Congressional Republicans and administration officials said they were close to a deal to keep the Bush-era tax cuts temporarily.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  White House officials and Congressional Republicans said Sunday they were closing in on a deal to temporarily continue the Bush-era tax cuts at all income levels, while bitterly frustrated Democratic Congressional leaders began exploring whether they would have the votes for such a package.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: In Online Privacy Plan, the Opt-Out Question Looms
articles.snippet: If all users refuse to allow tracking of their Internet activity, the proposed do-not-track system could cause major harm to online commerce, some experts say.
articles.abstract: If all users refuse to allow tracking of their Internet activity, the proposed do-not-track system could cause major harm to online commerce, some experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission’s proposed privacy mechanism could cause a major shift in the online advertising industry, as companies that have relied on consumers’ browsing history try to make up for what could be billions in lost revenue.
articles.byline: By TANZINA VEGA and VERNE KOPYTOFF

articles.headline: Studios Battle to Save Narnia (From Grip of Sequel Fatigue)
articles.snippet: If “The Voyage of the Dawn Treader” does not succeed, it is unlikely that the remaining four books in the series will be produced.
articles.abstract: If “The Voyage of the Dawn Treader” does not succeed, it is unlikely that the remaining four books in the series will be produced.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  With the opening this Friday of “The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader,” comes a study in one of the most difficult challenges a studio can face: fixing a broken movie series.

articles.headline: As U.S. Leaves, Iraqis Suffer Economic Toll
articles.snippet: Iraqis who made their living working for the American military and contractors are already feeling the effects.
articles.abstract: Iraqis who made their living working for the American military and contractors are already feeling the effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIKRIT, Iraq  Qahtan Kareem is a businessman whose main business  the United States  is leaving town. He made his fortune buying and reselling scrap and surplus from military bases. Now, as the American Army withdraws from Iraq, he is grim about the future of his company and its 430 employees.

articles.headline: Rabbit Ears Perk Up for Free HDTV
articles.snippet: Some people who are no longer willing or able to pay for TV have turned to the modern equivalent of the classic rabbit-ear antenna.
articles.abstract: Some people who are no longer willing or able to pay for TV have turned to the modern equivalent of the classic rabbit-ear antenna.
articles.lead_paragraph: Julie and Anthony Bayerl of St. Paul, Minn., love watching prime-time shows on the sleek 50-inch television in their bedroom. They also love that they pay nothing for the programming.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Google Opens Doors to E-Bookstore
articles.snippet: The Google eBookstore may be a boon to independent bookstores that have signed on to sell e-books on their Web sites through Google.
articles.abstract: The Google eBookstore may be a boon to independent bookstores that have signed on to sell e-books on their Web sites through Google.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Google e-bookstore is finally open.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Wal-Mart Appeal
articles.snippet: The issue in the biggest sex discrimination case on record is whether claims by employees may be merged.
articles.abstract: The issue in the biggest sex discrimination case on record is whether claims by employees may be merged.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear an appeal in the biggest employment discrimination case in the nation’s history, one claiming that Wal-Mart Stores had discriminated against hundreds of thousands of women in pay and promotion. The lawsuit seeks back pay that could amount to billions of dollars.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Steven Greenhouse
